Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Internal Tide and Mixing in Monterey and Ascension Canyons
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Based on theory, laboratory experiments and field observations, canyons have long been identified as sites of intense internal waves. Turbulence measurements in Monterey Canyon (MC) and density overturns in Kaoping Canyon (Taiwan), which has similar size and shape, confirm very strong mixing. The processes generating the mixing, however, have not been determined, nor has mixing been measured in enough canyons to assess its variability from one to another. Observations and recent modeling indicate that the internal tide is a major source of energy in Monterey Canyon, coming from offshore as well as being generated locally. In addition, ridges and constrictions along the canyon make it likely that lee waves and hydraulic jumps are also major sources of mixing, as has been inferred for abyssal canyons.

The project will undertake modeling and intensive observations for Monterey Canyon and exploration of nearby Ascension Canyon which is much straighter than Monterey and apparently lacks a significant offshore source for the internal tide. The goals are to: 1) understand how the internal tide propagates in canyons, and in particular how the M2 energy flux is steered around bends and when turns are so sharp that the energy is dissipated, 2) determine whether mixing locations and levels can be predicted by convergences in the along-canyon M2 energy flux, 3) identify and quantify mixing produced by internal wave scattering, lee waves and hydraulic jumps, and 4) assess the effects that canyon shape, smoothness and alignment with offshore M2 sources have on mixing and baroclinic energy by measuring mixing and the internal tide in a relatively short, straight canyon ending on the outer shelf.

Broader Impacts
U.S. coasts have dozens of canyons, and they account for almost half of the western continental slope from 45N to Alaska. Though they appear to be biologically rich and export both water and sediments, dynamical processes within canyons are too poorly understood to make a general assessment of the importance of canyons or whether they require special representation in large-scale or regional models. One set of measurements cannot resolve all questions about canyon dynamics, but the proposed work should provide qualitative and quantitative bases for assessing mixing in other canyons.. If fully successful, this project may unable the parameterization of some of the mixing or at least be able to point the way to parameterizations. As part of the proposed effort the investigators have also begun talks with regional modelers to incorporate intense canyon mixing into the models and to do sensitivity runs to define how accurately the mixing must be known to predict its effect on flows and structures outside the canyon. Two post-doc will be hired, one at APL/UW and another at the University of Hawaii. Both will
participate in all phases of the work for their postdoctoral training. Coordination and collaboration with the regular MBARI sampling of Monterey Bay will benefit this project, and vice versa. Outreach activities will combine earlier canyon measurements and the future measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was intended to advance the understanding of energetics in coastal canyons, with focus on internal tides. The investigation uses a combination of numerical and observational approaches. The numerical work is the focus of this grant (OCN0751226 to University of Hawaii) and the observational work is the focus of grant OCN0751420 to Applied Physics Laboratory / University of Washington. The primary study area was Monterey Submarine Canyon in central California, which is the largest submarine canyon on the west coast of the US. It extends from the abyssal plain at the base of the continental slope to within 100m of Moss Landing -- bisecting Monterey Bay. The bathymetry of the canyon is very complex, with several sharp meanders in the upper reaches and two smaller side-canyons. Although the canyon axis is nominally east-west there are sections where it is north-south. The University of Hawaii component of this project centered around high-resolution tidal simulations of the Monterey Bay region, including the submarine canyon (Figure 1).

Model output from this project has contributed to seven peered reviewed publications (5 are currently published and 2 are in the review process). In three of these seven publications the model results were the primary focus. 

The M2 (principal twice a day tide) depth-averaged current structure is a lot more complicated that the surface elevation changes would suggest. Monterey Bay co-oscillates, meaning the water-level raises and falls at the same time on both sides of the mouth of the bay. As the water-level is changing uniformly across the mouth of the bay, it might be expected that the flow is into (out of) the bay during flood (ebb) tide with a transport that balances the change in volume of the bay, also known as the tidal prism --- in which case the depth-averaged currents will be less than a millimeter per second. However, the model found that the M2 depth-averaged currents within the bay were spatially varying with magnitudes exceeding 0.1 m/s near Moss Landing. Figure 2 shows that when the depth-averaged currents are flowing into the bay through the canyon they are flowing out of the bay on the surrounding shelf. Having concurrent transports into and out of the bay allows the transport in one direction (e.g., into the bay) to exceed the tidal prism. This work suggests that mass conservation will result in the depth-averaged tidal currents transporting water from below the canyon rim over the shelf during flood tide. The implications of bringing potentially nutrient-rich water from the canyon on to the shelf were not explored.

Most of the M2 internal tide energy entering the canyon is generated to the south, on the flanks of Sur Platform or on the eastern flank of Smooth Ridge. The internal tide energy flux is strongest near the canyon floor, suggesting it is topographically steered around the canyon meanders. Net along-canyon energy flux decreases almost monotonically from 9 MW at the canyon mouth to 1 MW at Gooseneck Meander (a topographic feature about 10km from the canyon head), implying high levels of internal tide dissipation occur. The depth-integrated energy flux across the 200m depth contour is of order 10 W/m along the majority of the canyon rim, but increases by over an order of magnitude near the canyon head where internal tide energy escapes onto the shelf (Figure 3). 

Mooring observations collected as part of the companion project measured a near-surface stratification change in the upper canyon, likely caused by a seasonal shift in the prevailing wind that favored coastal upwelling. This change in near-surface stratification caused a transition in the behavior of the internal tide in the upper canyon from a partly standing wave during pre-upwelling conditions to a progressive wave during upwelling conditions...
